events.summary: Alberto Ginastera was born in Buenos Aires. Little did his parents know that their Spanish-Italian mix would eventually stir up quite the musical revolution in Argentina.

He graduated from the Williams Conservatory in Buenos Aires, officially becoming a music maker rather than just a music taker. It was a proud day for both him and his parents who could finally stop hearing him play scales.
Ginastera started teaching at the Liceo Militar General San Martín, where he probably inspired a bunch of cadets to write symphonies instead of just marching songs.
He took a trip to the United States to study with Aaron Copland at Tanglewood, where he absorbed the American spirit, all while avoiding burgers like an avant-garde musician does.
After his enlightening experience in the U.S., Ginastera returned to Buenos Aires, probably ready to jazz up the local music scene with some fresh sounds and witty anecdotes.
He founded the Julián Aguirre Conservatory of Music, where he could nurture young talents and make sure they didn't write just any old junk.
In 1968, Ginastera moved to the United States, likely in search of a bigger stage but also probably in need of a good taco.
He moved to Europe in 1970, bringing along his penchant for Nationalism and maybe a few incredible recipes that no one could really replicate.
Ginastera passed away in Geneva, Switzerland. The world bade adieu to a titan of music, likely with a slight shrug wondering what new melodies he might have conjured next.
